awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Variation in tick host preference and its epidemiological impact
awd_abstract_narration:
Ticks feed on many different host species, including humans. While doing so, they can contract and spread infectious diseases but it remains unclear which hosts and which ticks drive the prevalence of tick-borne diseases. This research focuses on the bacterium, Ehrlichia chaffeensis, which is carried by the Lone Star tick and is known to cause disease in humans and to infect white-tailed deer. Lone Star ticks also feed on a variety of other species, including raccoons and Virginia opossums, whose role in E. chaffeensis outbreaks is unclear. The aim of this project is to advance our understanding of the multi-host transmission of E. chaffeensis, with a particular focus on how ticks choose their hosts. Using a combination of experiments on tick behavior, studies of tick genetic variation, and mathematical modeling of disease transmission, this project will identify how tick feeding preferences and the variety of host species contribute to the spread of E. chaffeensis. 

This work is relevant to public health and wildlife management, and may lead to the development of effective tick-borne disease prevention and control strategies. Some of the field work will be conducted on state- and federally-owned land, and the findings will be shared with the managers of these properties. Several undergraduate students will participate in the research, and will be trained in cutting-edge molecular laboratory techniques that will both enhance their studies and advance the goals of this project.

Ticks feed on many different animal species, but not all of those species can be infected. Ticks cannot transmit disease directly to each other; they can only become infected by feeding on an infected animal. Likewise, animals only become infected with tick borne pathogens when infected ticks feed on them. This raises questions about how tick borne pathogens persist when ticks feed on a multitude of host animals that cannot become infected by or transmit pathogens to ticks.

We studied the persistence of tick borne pathogens by looking at how ticks interact with their host animals. We focused our research on ticks that transmit disease to both wildlife and humans. Our research addressed three specific questions, with the following results:

1. Do ticks detect host animal scent, and do they prefer certain scents?

The Lone Star tick (Amblyomma americanum) spreads the disease Human Monocytic Ehrlichiosis. This disease is caused by the bacterium Ehrlichia chaffeensis, and white-tailed deer are the only known wildlife species that can become infected with this pathogen and transmit it to ticks. We studied whether juvenile A. americanum are attracted to the scents of white-tailed deer and other ticks hosts (opossums, raccoons, and bobcats).

We found that the ticks are attracted to certain individuals scents, but are not broadly attracted to any one species. We also found that when ticks are presented two multiple scents simultaneously, they prefer closest scent regardless of species.

Previous field studies show that some animals are disproportionately parasitized by ticks, and scent may help explain this variation. Determining why some animals are highly parasitized can provide valuable information on how to develop new tick-preventive treatments for wildlife. This research serves as a foundation for further study on how scent influences tick feeding decisions. 

2. Does tick population genetic structure reflect the feeding choices of adult ticks?

Many tick species also mate on their host animals. Consequently, ticks can only mate with other ticks on the same animal. We hypothesized that if ticks have genetically determined preferences for certain host species that it would result in genetic drift. Genetic drift is the random accummulation of DNA mutations, and over time different mutations accummulate in isolated populations. Genetic drift can be detected from DNA sequence data; we looked for genetic drift in tick populations to support our hypothesis that ticks have genetically determined host preferences.

We looked specifically at Dermacentor variabilis ticks, which are the vectors of Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever. We collected D. variabilis directly from raccoons and opossums at two different collection sites. We then sequenced the DNA of those ticks, identified variations in DNA sequence, and looked to see if any variations correlated with host species identity.

In conjunction with this research, we also refined laboratory procedures for DNA sequencing and refined computational methods for analyzing DNA sequence data. We did not find strong genetic evidence that ticks prefer raccoons over opossums or vice versa, but we did make substantial improvements to the methods for analyzing sequence data. We used the tick sequence data to show the influence of the type of analysis on results, and developed guidelines for how data should be processed and how many individuals should be sampled to get robust results.
